intro: Origanum vulgare var. albidum, commonly known as white marjoram, is a perennial herb native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It is characterized by its small, pale yellow to white flowers and slender, aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained soils in full sun. Its essential oils, derived from the leaves and flowers, contain compounds like carvacrol and thymol, which contribute to its medicinal and culinary uses. White marjoram is often used in herbal teas and as a spice in Mediterranean cuisine.
